summary: Email correspondence between a Senior Forensic Examiner (NY CART Coordinator) and a US Attorney's Office (USANYS) contractor regarding the processing and tracking of forensic evidence (digital devices) from the Epstein investigation. The examiner clarifies discrepancies in evidence item numbers (NYC numbers) and provides updates on the forensic extraction process.

persons.name: Sunny Drescher
persons.role: Contractor at US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS)
persons.context: Appears as the initial recipient of the email chain, though the main correspondence is between the forensic examiner and another USANYS contractor.

events.title: Forensic examiner sends initial evidence spreadsheet
events.description: A Senior Forensic Examiner (NY CART Coordinator) sends a spreadsheet of evidence items to the US Attorney's Office.

events.title: Follow-up on forensic evidence processing
events.description: Email exchange clarifying discrepancies in evidence item numbers (NYC024328, NYC024392) and providing updates on the status of forensic processing of devices seized in the investigation.

keyFacts: The document is a forensic evidence tracking email from July 2020, showing active post-mortem investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's case.
Multiple digital devices (computers, hard drives, iPads, phones) are being processed under specific NYC evidence numbers (e.g., NYC024363, NYC024392).
A Senior Forensic Examiner (NY CART Coordinator) is handling the extraction and clarifies that an item listed as 'not ready' (NYC024392) had already been unlocked and downloaded.
The evidence processing was temporarily halted because 'HQ took our system down for some urgent patches.'
The correspondence is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence being discussed.
